title: Namdapha National Park
short_description: India's third-largest national park, a biodiversity hotspot in Arunachal Pradesh hosting four big cat species.
long_description: Namdapha National Park is the largest protected area in the Eastern Himalaya biodiversity hotspot and is located in Changlang district of Arunachal Pradesh. It is India's third largest national park. The park is a botanical and zoological treasure trove, with an altitude varying from 200 m to 4500 m. It is notoriously famous for being the only park in the world to harbour four feline species of big cats: Tiger, Leopard, Snow Leopard and Clouded Leopard. Its remote location and dense canopy keep much of it unexplored and pristine.
wildlife_significance: Only park with Tiger, Leopard, Snow Leopard, and Clouded Leopard. Extremely high endemism.
guides_and_tips: Requires an Inner Line Permit (ILP) for Arunachal Pradesh + Park Permit. Prepare for no connectivity and basic stays.
how_to_reach: By Air: Dibrugarh (160 km). By Rail: Tinsukia (140 km). Then by road to Miao (entry point).
permits_and_fees: Obtain ILP online. Park permit at Miao Field Director office.
conservation_notes: Challenges include poaching and critical habitat preservation for the Hoolock Gibbon.
sample_itinerary: Day 1: Arrive Dibrugarh, drive to Miao. Obtain permits. Day 2: Drive to Deban. Cross river. Trek to Hornbill Camp. Day 3: Birding trek to Bulbulia. Day 4: Return trek to Deban. Day 5: Departure.
safety_tips: Leeches are abundant. Rain is unpredictable. Hire a local guide for safety.

operating_season.season_notes: Accessible only in dry months due to river crossings.

pricing_metadata.disclaimer: Remote location; prices for porters/transport vary.
